The CAD I selected is inverted, I cannot indicate it... As the soggetto of 'Vidi speciosam'is used again on 'Cuius inastimabilis', I have selected the latter, though I do not describe it. (after reflection, I find the actual CAD on bar 28, it could be the model of the CAD in the mass. I will indicate it in another comment)

The fuga is based on an ID I have already asserted in another comment. It is hard to find any other structural element in this fuga, as it is quite free. The first kyrie is based on only one element, leading to the CAD.

In the second duo, the first entry has been anticipated, so that the counterpoint is the one of an ID, even though the time interval of entries is not 'regular'. The Primis Tenor enters in imitation, turning the ID into a Fg.

If we consider that the 5th entry starts at the beginning of the 9th bar, the time interval becomes S3/5/3/5/2.

The end of the soggetto (the diatonic descent) is used as a counter-soggetto of its own, becoming independent on 'circumdabant'. This fact is important for Sohier will use this characteristic to produce a figuralism. I consider that the third entry, on the contra, starts one M later, for it is the only one that is 'flexed'.

The counter-soggetto is used to make a figuralism on 'descendit de'. It is anticipated at the bassus on 'Qui proper nos". As this diatonic descent is also the end of soggetto, it can be considered as anticipated by the soggetto ('Qui propter nos homines, et proper nostram').

The first two entrances are strict, as usual; the third is freely diminished in rhythm and lacks its final note (or one could say the final melodic interval is flexed from a 2nd, A-G to a 3rd, A-F)

The altus and bassus make use of two repeated motives: (1) a rising "cumulative fourth" consisting of a rising second + rising third in minims, and (2) a stepwise falling fourth in dotted minim & crotchets. In one place in the altus the two motives are spliced together to form a countermelody beneath the first note of the soggetto; otherwise they occur separately. The motives don't line up with the subject consistently, so they don't form NIms. Could be considered "contrapunto fugato"?
New material in Gombert related to the descending thirds from the 2nd and 4th phrases of the Cadéac in a new combination

Superius/tenor in strict fuga at the lower fifth as usual. Third entrance in the altus truncated after its fourth note, after which it continues in free counterpoint. Fourth entrance dubious, if it is considered an imitative entrance at all: it comprises only the first two notes, with the interval between them flexed from a 2nd to a 3rd.

The chant melody has a built-in repetition at this point, and Mouton sets both repetitions identically, meaning that the complete four-voice complex formed by superius/tenor fuga + free altus and bassus is immediately repeated, without any change or exchange of voices.

These are 4-voice NIMs, in which the ornamented chant melody provides one subject. The second presentation is rotated (invertible counterpoint): countersubject three, which was in the bassus in the first presentation, is now moved up an octave into the contratenor. There is a brief suggestion of fuga on countersubject 2 in the first three notes of the quinta vox in b. 14.

This is really an MTI presentation. Josquin brings in fuga entrances of the chant-derived descending-fourth motive alternately at 2-sb and 1-sb time intervals. As a result, the lattice of entrances involves *two* different repeated imitative duos, both altered  through ic12. Entrances separated by 2sb are at 8+ and 5-; entrances separated by 1sb are at 4- and 9+.

The chant is used as the subject of a complex passage involving both fuga and non-imitative duos (Tenor
Sexta pars
Cantus 
Bassus). The most extensive entrances are in the tenor and cantus; the other voices take only a three-note head-motive from the chant melody. The combination of the long tenor entrance with the three-note head-motive in the sexta pars forms a miniature imitative duo which is repeated by the cantus and bassus. More significant modular repetition arises from the presence of countersubjects (analysed separately)
This is the simpler of the two non-imitative modules in which the chant soggetto participates in this passage

This is a *3-voice* NIm with two presentations. The top voice has a three-note head-motive derived from the chant; the middle voice is an independent motive consisting of a rising fourth followed by a cantizans cadence; the bottom voice begins with the same three-note head-motive (rhythmicised differently) followed by a motive which engages in voice-exchange with the middle voice. In the first presentation of the module, the first three notes of the rising-fourth motive complete a statement of the chant soggetto (see the relationship recording details of the fuga in this passage). In the second NIm presentation this motive occurs independently, without the preceding chant segment.

As in the previous section there are two substantial entrances of a chant-derived soggetto, and two fragmentary entrances of its three-note head-motive (both in the altus). The latter do not participate in any modular repetition (see other relationship for details of the NIm in this section) and are probably opportunistic entrances, perhaps (hypothetically) the last to be "fitted in" to an existing structure in the compositional process?

This is a *3-voice* NIm with *4* different motives. For the purposes of this relationship only the portion of the chant soggetto that participates in the NIm is shown, although in both cases it is part of a longer fuga entrances. Motive 1 (A-G-F) comes from the chant at "-gris medi-"; motive 2 (G-F-E-C-D) is always heard in one of the bass voices, followed by tenorizans or basizans motion; motive 3 (A-B-C-A) is usually heard in an inner voice; motive 4 is a decorated cantizans cadence. We hear two different three-voice combinations of these four motives in alteration: first 1+2+3, then 2+3+4, then repeat. In other words, motives 2+3 are heard each time, in combination either with the soggetto (motive 1) or with the cantizans cadence (motive 4)

Pieton has concealed the underlying periodicity of this fuga: if we judge from the *second* note of the chant soggetto, this is a PEn(sta) with entrances at the semibreve at the upper fourth. However, the variable length of the subject's first note conceals this regularity, to the extent that the tenor entrance on G which begins first is actually the *comes* to the *dux* represented by the sexta pars entrance on D. The third entrance in the quinta pars is fragmentary.

The first four notes of the chant participate in a small NIm with a countersubject consisting of a falling third + rising fourth. The first presentation is complicated by offsetting the countersubject by one minim. The second exchanges the parts in ic12.

The chant motive (a descending fourth) is first quoted in simplified form by the quinta pars; then there is a 2vv. fuga on an ornamented form of the subject in which added notes change its stepwise descent into alternating falling thirds and rising seconds

The ornamented chant soggetto in the cantus provides a quasi-cantus-firmus (or a "declamatory singleton" in Schubert's terms?) below which the lower five voices engage in fuga on a four-note motive (G-A-F-G: rising second-falling third-rising second). The entrances are initially periodic every two minims; then there is a group of three entrances which enter every four minims, and finally a closing imitative duo again at two minims. Not explicitly indicated in the data above are a possible entrance of the motive in inversion (sexta pars, bb. 45-46: E-D-F-E) and one in shadowing/fauxbourdon (altus, bb. 45-46: A-B-G-A)

The chant soggetto is in the cantus, beneath which the other voices engage in stretto fuga based on falling fourths and rising thirds; this pattern automatically generates imitations in ic12, permitting entrances at the lower octave and upper fifth. Following the end of the chant soggetto in the cantus, the complete three-voice fuga lattice plus the free continuations that follow each of its entrances is repeated at the same pitch, forming a *3-voice* NIm.

The subject is formed into fuga in two groups of periodic entrances separated by a cadence; since the countersubject in the altus is repeated with the second group of three entrances, they form a four-voice repeated NIm. Only two voices of the NIm - the altus and bassus, which have the greatest overlap - have been formally noted in this assertion.

The material Willaert borrowed from b. 55 is part of a NIm in Josquin, not noted here because the other subject is not borrowed.

Every movement of the Willaert piece is structured as a double canon for [discantus], [contratenor primus], tenor and bassus (in some order).  Since the time and pitch interval between the first and second pairs of voices is always the same, every section consists of overlapping ID presentations. Only the portion of the ID which also participates in the NIm is selected here.

This duo begins imitatively with entrances of a 3-note head motive, followed by differing continuations; the continuation of the upper/leading entrance in Josquin's duos is not borrowed and is not indicated here.

The IDs arise as a consequence of the double-canon structure; only the portion involving borrowed material is highlighted here. The borrowed soggetto divides into two motives (A-Bb-A and A-G-A-Bb-A), which Willaert brings back at the conclusion of the canonic phrase in the upper voices. Their overlapping with the repetition of the opening duo in the lower voices results in additional fuga and NIms where the four voices overlap in bb. 40--48

This is one voice of a NIm in Josquin's motet; the other subject is not selected as it is not borrowed here (it was used on its own as a countersubject in Willaert's first point of imitation).
This segment of the double canon is heard only once (it is not repeated by the lower voices) due to its proximity to the final cadence of the section.

The subject ends with a cantizans cadence, the countersubject with a tenorizans cadence. Josquin first presents the subject and countersubject as singletons, then in NIm combination. Two more presentations of the NIm flex the subject and retain only the tail of the countersubject (it is joined to a new head-motive, not borrowed and so not indicated here).

Within the context of the double-canon, Willaert contrives to quote Josquin's NIm in two different ways.  The initial canonic entrances of the borrowed subject (tenor/bassus) are accompanied by the borrowed countersubject in the free voices (contratenor secundus/vagans). The second set of canonic entrances (discantus/contratenor primus) overlap with the tail of the canon in the lower voices, and Willaert concludes the canonic phrase with the countersubject so that the overlap of the voice pairs produces two more presentations of the NIm (inverted and transposed). The end of the canonic phrase in the upper voices accordingly produces two final entrances of the countersubject without the accompanying subject.

This seems like it will be a NIm, like the previous point of imitation, with which it shares a chant soggetto. But the two subjects only line up at their first appearance (the countersubject beginning a third below the subject). Subsequent entrances get "out of phase": in the second entrance of the two soggetti, the countersubject begins 2 minims later than the subject, an 11th below; in the third entrance of the two, the countersubject begins four minims later and a 7th below, so there are three different S/CS cells. There is also an added entry of the chant motive in the cantus of b. 84-5.

The first entrance in the altus is flexed and the final entrance in the same voice is truncated; the others are strict. It's interesting that Mouton's treatment of the chant in this secunda pars is usually fairly straightforward contrapuntally, with the exceptions of the more complex passages of fuga here and at "quo salvantur omnia" (b. 105). Is this a reflection of the importance of these parts of the text, or is it simply motivated musically by these chant fragments being easier to form into fuga?

This borrowing is described in Bernadette Nelson's 2002 article: see ex. 4, p. 371. Morales has taken a complete four-voice complex from Mouton, consisting of two voices in fuga together with their accompanying "free" voices. Morales'repetition of the borrowed material produces a quasi-NIm, though neither figure taken from the free voices is repeated exactly in its entirety. Only the conclusion of the borrowed material in the bassus is repeated (C-D-E-D in b. 9-10 becomes F-G-G-A-G in b. 12-13, with the addition of an octave leap). Meanwhile, only the skeleton of the borrowed motive in the tenor of b. 9-10 is repeated in the altus of b. 12-13, omitting the cantizans cadence; however, because the added head motive in b. 8-9/11-12 is also repeated, the entrance maintains its identity as a countersubject to the main chant soggetto.

The chant melody is heard in cantus-firmus fashion three times: first incomplete in the tenor; then complete and ornamented in the cantus; finally complete and unornamented in the tenor. These statements are combined with entrances of a "countersubject" in the other voices, but it does not line up to form modules; instead, it combines with the cantus firmus in varying ways in "contrapunto fugato" fashion. (The first three entrances of the countersubject are periodic, but without enough overlap to produce modular repetition).
These entrances are part of a repeated NIm in Josquin, but Morales has borrowed only the countersubject, omitting Josquin's ornamented chant soggetto.

This captures only two single entrances from a complex passage of MTI fuga in Josquin; none of these contrapuntal relationships are borrowed by Morales, only the outline of the soggetto itself, so it does not seem worth detailing them. See the relationship between this Josquin passage and the chant model for details of the complete fuga lattice.

The altus shadows the bassus in bb. 105-7 and 109-10. Not notated in this relationship but also contributing to the complexity of the passage is the presence of a cantus firmus drawn from a different chant segment in the cantus of bb. 97-102.

This is a massive MTI presentation with repeating modules at S1, S2 and S3 time intervals. Its full form would require further analysis, but two features stand out immediately: (1) there is an element of heightening tension in the way that Morales draws the final four entrances into closer stretto ; (2) there is a subtle element of formal return or 'framing'in the fact that a stretto interlock at the S1 time interval is used only at the beginning and at the end.

This passage consists of two presentations of a three-voice complex consisting of two voices in flexed fuga with a countersubject. There is a lot of flexing and re-splicing going on in the second presentation of this three-voice complex, so the beginnings and endings are the same, but the middle is different, and the voice roles are reshuffled.

The form of this fuga can be thought of as ABA. Each A consists of three entrances in the lower three voices (altus/bassus/tenor), with the first two in close fuga and the third a near-singleton (M1/6; 5-5+ in the first A, 5-1+ in the second). The B is the cantus entrance in bb. 74--75. Also, the pattern of which entrances are the original form and which the alternative "flexed" form is interesting: if X is the original and Y the form that first appears in the cantus singleton entrance, the pattern is XXXY(Y')YX, with (Y') representing a form with additional flexing at its last interval. In short, there are ABA forms on two different levels. (Is there possible symbolism somehow relating this to "crucifixus"?)

The last two fuga entrances are tricky: because the first note of the bassus entrance is lengthened from a minim to a dotted semibreve, the bassus enters one minim earlier than the altus; nevertheless, from the second note of the subject onwards the altus functions as the guide and the bassus as the consequent, following the altus one minim *later* and repeating the imitative duo of the first two entrances in the passage. The data above reflect this "normalized" view of the contrapuntal relationship rather than the literal relationships between each entrance's first note.

The NIm formed by the borrowed subject with a new CS is presented twice in complete form, and a final time in fragmentary form (retaining only the last 3 notes of the CS). The third "presentation" is barely there at all: it shares only two notes of the CS with the others. It is included in this analysis only because of the interesting cadential contrast: the other 3 presentations imply but evade a cadence, whereas in this one the cantizans cadence figure is completed.

The first two presentations of the borrowed NIm are formed by one of its two subjects in the canonic voices, with the other subject introduced in the free voices. The latter two presentations occur where the end of one canonic duo in the tenor and bassus overlaps with the start of the next canonic duo in the discantus and contratenor: here, Willaert has ended the canonic subject with one of the NIm subjects, so that the overlap of the two canonic duos produces two more NIm presentations. (This is a technique Willaert uses elsewhere in the mass).

These head-motives are followed by longer continuations which, in canon, form an extended ID; they are analysed simply as fuga here since there is no substantial overlap between each entrance of the common head motive.
